Immobilized palladium nanoparticles on potassium zirconium phosphate as an efficient recoverable heterogeneous catalyst for a clean Heck reaction in flow Chiara Petrucci a Matteo Cappelletti a Oriana Piermatti a ⁎ Morena Nocchetti b Monica Pica b Ferdinando Pizzo a Luigi Vaccaro a ⁎ a Laboratory of Green Synthetic Organic Chemistry, CEMIN – Dipartimento di Chimica, Biologiae Biotecnologie, Università di Perugia, Via Elce di Sotto, 8; Perugia, Italy Laboratory of Green Synthetic Organic Chemistry CEMIN – Dipartimento di Chimica, Biologiae Biotecnologie Università di Perugia Via Elce di Sotto, 8 Perugia Italy b Dipartimento di Scienze Farmaceutiche, Università di Perugia, Via Fabretti; Perugia, Italy Dipartimento di Scienze Farmaceutiche Università di Perugia Via Fabretti; Perugia Italy ⁎ Corresponding authors. Tel.: +39 755855559; fax: +39 755855560. Graphical abstract Palladium nanoparticles on layered potassium α-zirconium phosphate (PdNP/α-ZrPK) with high palladium loading (10.6wt%) have been prepared and used as catalyst in low amount (0.1mol% of Pd) in the Heck reaction of methyl acrylate and styrene with a series of aryl iodides in CH3CN/H2O azeotrope as a green medium. The procedure has been optimized under flow conditions obtaining an extremely low waste production (E-factor) and allowing to isolate the final product with very low residual palladium content without any purification step. Keywords Heck reaction Heterogeneous catalysis Palladium nanoparticles Recoverable reaction media Flow chemistry 1 Introduction Heck reaction is one of the most powerful and widely used methods to couple alkenes with aryl halides [1–3]. The resulting products have found extensive applications as intermediates in the preparation of materials [4–8], natural products and bioactive compounds [9–14]. Problems associated with separation and recovery of homogeneous palladium catalysts represent major limit in the industrial and synthetic applications of Heck reaction. This latter aspect, together with the high cost of metal catalysts and their known toxic effects, have led to an increased interest in immobilizing metal catalysts onto solid supports [2,15–17]. In fact, recoverable and reusable heterogeneous catalysts may significantly help to minimize waste production contributing to the development of sustainable chemical processes [18–21]. A variety of organic and inorganic supports have been explored to develop efficient heterogenous palladium sources [2,3,17,22]. Recently, supported metal palladium nanoparticles (PdNPs) with a high surface to volume ratio have attracted a great deal of attention as stable and recoverable ligand-free catalysts. [23–28]. It has been recently reported that palladium nanoparticles immobilized on various supports have been employed in the Heck reaction [29–33]. However the stability and reactivity of these catalytic systems are highly dependent on the support used for the immobilization. Therefore, the search for new efficient supports for catalytically active palladium nanoparticles is a wide ongoing area of research. Tetravalent metal phosphates and phosphonates featuring a layered structure are attracting supports for metal nanoparticles because of their chemical and thermal stability [34] and high versatility [35–42]. In addition, since they are insoluble in water and organic solvents, they can be easily recovered by simple filtration or centrifugation and efficiently reused [35–51]. Layered zirconium hydrogen phosphate with an α-type structure (α-Zr(HPO4)2·H2O) is a well known material, consisting of layers made of planes of zirconium atoms bonded to monohydrogen phosphate groups, on both sides of each plane. Several monovalent and divalent cations are able to exchange the α-ZrP protons, thus providing a variety of ionic groups on the layer surface. It was found that the presence of cations, such as Na+ and K+, in the ion exchange sites of the support, improves the catalytic properties for metallic silver particles [52]. As a matter of fact, these cations turned out to stabilize the silver catalyst, by blocking the exchange sites for the Ag+ ions, thus hindering their back diffusion [52]. Therefore, layered potassium α-zirconium phosphate α-Zr(KPO4)2 (hereafter α-ZrPK) is a promising support for the immobilization and stabilization of palladium nanoparticles. Recently, we have been involved in the development of novel solid catalysts to be used in benign reaction media for the definition of environmentally-efficient processes [43–48,53–57]. In this contribution we report the preparation of PdNPs supported on layered potassium α-zirconium phosphate as catalyst for the Heck cross-coupling reaction. The main goal of this study is the preparation of highly-performing heterogeneous Pd catalysts able to be used efficiently in sustainable reaction media, in order to develop an environmentally friendly method for the Heck reaction. As a matter of fact, Heck reaction is usually carried out in aprotic polar solvent such us N,N’-dimethylformamide (DMF) and N-methylpyrrolidone (NMP), which are among the most undesirable media, because of their toxicity and difficult disposal [58,59]. In this contribution we have investigated the use of the prepared catalytic material in the azeotropic mixture CH3CN/H2O 84% as a safer and easily recoverable reaction medium, alternative to conventional dipolar aprotic media. In fact, in coupling processes such as Heck reaction, the need of combined organic/aqueous media is common to reach highest efficiency. We are investigating, at this purpose, the use of aqueous azeotropes which is truly interesting because, while they combine the properties of organic and aqueous media, they also have the potential of being recovered at the end of the reaction and reused without increasing the amount of waste. Moreover, in this case acetonitrile is an acceptable solvent, recommended as alternative to DMF or NMP [58,59]. To the best of our knowledge, this is the first example of the use of layered α-ZrPK as palladium support in acetonitrile/water azeotrope. The base has a fundamental role in the Heck reaction mechanism, since it regenerates the active Pd species in the last step of the catalytic cycle. Although, homogeneous bases such as triethylamine (TEA) are generally used, thus work up procedures are needed to isolate the pure products. In view of waste minimization, we were able to avoid wasteful work up procedures using a polystyrene-supported base (PS-TEA), removable by simple filtration. In addition, the use of flow technology may offer several advantages as compared to traditional batch reactor. Flow reactors have proved to be efficient tools to optimize the recovery and reuse of the catalyst, minimize waste and in particular the amount of organic solvent needed to isolate the final products [60]. After optimization of the reaction in batch conditions, we applied the flow technology for the development of sustainable protocol for Heck reaction. 2 Experimental 2.1 General remarks All chemicals were purchased and used without any further purification. 1H NMR, and 13C NMR spectra were recorded at 400MHz and 100.6MHz, respectively, on a Bruker DRX-ADVANCE 400MHz in CDCl3 using TMS as the internal standard. Zr and Pd analyses were performed on a ICP Varian Liberty inductively coupled plasma-optical emission spectrometry (ICP-OES) with axial injection. C, H, N elemental analyses (EA) were performed on a Fisons EA1108CHN. X-ray diffraction patterns (XRPD) of powders were collected with a Philips X’Pert PRO MPD diffractometer operating at 40kV and 40mA, with a step size 0.03341 and step scan 40s, using Cu Kα radiation and an X’Celerator detector. Transmission electron microscopy (TEM) analysis was carried out by a Philips 208 transmission electron microscope, operating at an accelerating voltage of 100kV. Powders were rapidly diluted in ethanol, then supported on copper grids (200 mesh) precoated with Formvar carbon films, and quickly dried. GLC analyses were performed by using Hewlett-Packard HP 5890 A equipped with a capillary column DB-35MS (30m, 0.53mm), a FID detector and hydrogen as gas carrier. GC-EIMS analyses were carried out by using a Hewlett-Packard HP 6890N Network GC system/5975 Mass Selective Detector equipped with an electron impact ionizer at 70eV. Thin layer chromatography analyses were performed with silica gel on aluminum plates (silica gel 60 F254, Fluka). Column chromatography purification was performed with silica gel (230–400 mesh) eluting with hexane or mixture hexane/ethyl acetate (98:2–70:30). Melting points are uncorrected and were measured on a Büchi 510. Flow procedures were performed using a Jasco PU-2080HPLC pump, a Omnifit glass column as reservoir and a Supelco HPLC column blank as the base/catalyst column. All the equipment was connected using 1/16′ OD PTFE tubing and stainless steel 1/16 ODx0.02 ID capillary tubing and Hamilton HPV Plug Valves. The system was placed in a ventilated Plexiglas box equipped with a electrical resistance heating. Diethylaminomethyl-polystyrene (PS-TEA) was prepared by reacting Merrifield resin (200–400 mesh, 4.4mmol/g Cl loading, 2% cross-linked with divinylbenzene) with diethylamine (2.5 equiv) in toluene at 100°C for 24h. The resin was then washed with a 0.5M solution of diethylamine in toluene, then toluene, dichloromethane, water and acetone to remove the excess amine, then dried under vacuum. The loading of amine is calculated by C, H, N elemental analysis (EA) on the element nitrogen, which is not contained in the purified and fully dried polimeric support. Solid NMR analyze also confirm the absence of free amine. Compounds 3a [61], 3b [61], 3c [61], 3d [62], 3e [61], 3f [63], 3g [62], 3h [61], 6a [61], 6b [64], 6c [61], 6d [65], 6e [61], 6f [66], 6g [65], 6h [66] are known. 2.2 Preparation of α-Zr(KPO4)2, (α-ZrPK) α-ZrPK was obtained by titration with KOH 0.1M in KCl 0.1M of α-Zr(HPO4)2·H2O, prepared according to Alberti and Costantino method [67]. To a suspension of α-Zr(HPO4)2·H2O (2g, 6.64mmol) in KCl 0.1M (300mL), KOH 0.1M (133mL) was added slowly, under stirring, keeping the pH below 9. The titration is complete in about three days (the complete potassium exchange is verified by XRPD analysis). The obtained α-ZrPK was separated from aqueous medium by centrifugation, washed with water (3×100mL) and finally dried at 80°C for 24h (2.2g). 2.3 Preparation of PdNP/α-ZrPK To a suspension of α-ZrPK (0.5g) in ethanol (25mL), palladium acetate (0.112g, 0.5mmol) was added and the mixture stirred at 50°C for 20h. Then, the obtained dark solid material was separated by centrifugation, washed with ethanol (2×10mL) and dried at 50°C for 24h (0.46g). The PdNP/α-ZrPK catalyst was characterized by using ICP-OES, XRPD and TEM techniques. 2.3.1 E-factor calculations for the preparation of PdNP/α-ZrPK E-factor=[0.5g (α-ZrPK)+19.72g (ethanol)+0.112g (Pd(OAc)2)+15.78g (ethanol wash)−0.460g (PdNP/α-ZrPK)]/0.460g (PdNP/α-ZrPK)=77.5. 2.3.2 Determination of Pd content A weighed amount of the PdNP/α-ZrPK catalyst was first treated with concentrated HF in order to dissolve α-ZrPK, then with aqua regia to digest the Pd species, and the obtained solution was diluted with deionized water and analyzed by ICP-OES. The Pd content was determined to be 1mmol/g, which is equal to 10.6wt% Pd loading. 2.4 General procedure for the Heck reaction under batch conditions To a solution of the aryl iodide 1a–h (1mmol) and the alkene 2 or 5 (1.2mmol) in CH3CN/H2O az. (1M, 1mL), triethylamine (TEA, 1.2mmol) and catalyst PdNP/α-ZrPK (0.1mol%, 1mg) were added. The reaction mixture was stirred at 120°C for 3h with methyl acrylate (2) and for 4h with styrene (5); the conversion of the aryl iodide 1a–h was monitored by GLC analyses. The reaction mixture was diluted with water (2mL) and extracted with ethyl acetate (3×3mL). The combined organic layers were dried with sodium sulfate and evaporated under reduced pressure to give the products 3a–h and 6a–h. 2.4.1 Representative E-factor calculations for batch reaction with TEA E-factor for Heck reaction of iodobenzene (1a) (1mmol) and methyl acrylate (2) (1.2mmol) (98% isolated yield): E-factor=[0.204g (iodobenzene (1a))+0.103g (methyl acrylate (2))+0.121g (TEA)+0.818g (1mL CH3CN/H2O 84:16)+2g (water)+8.1g (ethyl acetate)−0.159g (methyl cinnamate (3a))]/0.159 g (methyl cinnamate (3a))=70.4. (catalyst was not considered due to its recovery and recycle) 2.5 General procedure for recovery and reuse of PdNP/α-ZrPK in the Heck reaction under batch conditions To a solution of iodobenzene (1a, 6mmol) and methyl acrylate (2, 7.2mmol) in CH3CN/H2O az. (1M, 6mL), triethylamine (7.2mmol) and catalyst PdNP/α-ZrPK (0.1mol%, 6mg) were added. The reaction mixture was stirred at 120°C for 3h; the conversion of the iodobenzene (1a) was monitored by GLC analyses. The solid catalyst was separated by centrifugation and then washed with CH3CN/H2O az. (2×1mL), dried at 50°C for 3h and reused in a successive cycle. The product 3a was isolated after extraction with ethyl acetate. 2.6 General procedure for the Heck reaction in presence of PS-TEA under batch conditions To a solution of iodobenzene (1a, 1mmol) and methyl acrylate (2, 1.2mmol) in CH3CN/H2O az. (1M, 1mL), diethylaminomethyl-polystyrene (PS-TEA, 3.84mmol/g, 1.2 equiv, 0.312g) and catalyst PdNP/α-ZrPK (0.1mol%, 1mg) were added. The reaction mixture was stirred at 120°C for 3h; the conversion of the iodobenzene (1a) was monitored by GLC analyses. The heterogeneous base and catalyst were separated by filtration and the product 3a isolated by distillation of the azeotrope. 2.6.1 Representative E-factor calculations for the batch reaction with PS-TEA E-factor for Heck reaction of iodobenzene (1a) (1mmol) and methyl acrylate (2) (1.2mmol) (96% isolated yield): E-factor=[0.204g (iodobenzene (1a))+0.103g (methyl acrylate (2))+0.312g (PS-TEA)+0.001g (PdNP/α-ZrPK)+0.818g (1mL CH3CN/H2O 84:16)−0.155g (methyl cinnamate (3a))]/0.155g (methyl cinnamate (3a))=8.3. 2.7 Heck reaction of iodobenzene (1a) and methyl acrylate (2) under flow conditions A pre-mixed mixture of iodobenzene (1a) (50mmol, 5.60mL) and methyl acrylate (2) (60mmol, 5.40mL) in CH3CN/H2O az. (50mL) was charged into a glass column functioning as a reservoir. Diethylaminomethyl-polystyrene (3.84mmol/g, 75mmol, 19.5g) and the catalyst PdNP/α-ZrPK (0.1mol%, 50mg) were mixed and dispersed in 1mm diameter solid glass beads and charged in a stainless steel HPLC column; the equipment was connected, by using the appropriate valves, to a pump and installed into a thermostated box. The reaction mixture was continuously pumped (flow rate 2.0mL/min) through the base - catalyst column at 130°C until complete conversion of reactants to methyl cinnamate (3a) was achieved (the reaction was monitored by GLC). At this stage, the pump was left to run in order to recover the reaction mixture into the reservoir. To completely recover the product and clean the reactor, CH3CN/H2O azeotrope (3×25mL at a 2mL/min) was cyclically pumped through the base - catalyst column for 15min (each fraction) and then collected into the reservoir to isolate the product in 89 % yield, after removal and recovery of the azeotrope (95% of which was recovered) via distillation. 2.7.1 Representative E-factor calculations for the reaction in flow at 120°C E-factor for Heck reaction of iodobenzene (1a) (50mmol) and methyl acrylate (2) (60mmol) (89% isolated yield): E-factor=[10.20g (iodobenzene (1a))+5.40g (methyl acrylate (2))+102.25g (medium)+19.5g (PS-TEA)+0.050g (catalyst)−7.20g (methyl cinnamate (3a))−97.15g (95% recovered medium)]/7.20g (methyl cinnamate (3a))=4.6. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Catalyst preparation and characterization The layered potassium α-zirconium phosphate (α-ZrPK), has been easily prepared by titration with 2 equiv. of KOH of a suspension of α-zirconium hydrogen phosphate, α-Zr(HPO4)2·H2O, in a 1M solution of KCl [67]. The solid was separated by centrifugation, washed with water and dried at 80°C for 24h. We decided to prepare the heterogeneous palladium catalyst by the immobilization of palladium nanoparticles (PdNPs) on α-ZrPK using the method of alcohol reduction of palladium acetate [24,29]. To a suspension of α-ZrPK in EtOH, palladium acetate (1mmol for 1g of support) was added and the mixture stirred at 50°C for 20h. The PdNP/α-ZrPK was separated by centrifugation, washed with ethanol and dried at 50°C for 24h. The PdNP/α-ZrPK was characterized by using ICP-OES, XPRD and TEM techniques. Fig. 1 shows two representative TEM micrographs of PdNP/α-ZrPK before the catalytic tests. The surface of the α-ZrPK platelets is decorated with the PdNPs, which show an almost spherical morphology, and a relatively good monodispersity. The PdNPs size range from 5 to 20nm. The XRPD of the catalyst (Fig. 2 ) shows the typical (002) reflection of anhydrous α-ZrPK (2θ =10°), suggesting that the interlayer region did not undergo significant modifications during the preparation of the catalyst. Additional reflections in the range 35–70° 2θ were assigned to the (111), (200) and (220) crystalline planes of the typical cubic phase of metallic palladium (JCPDS #05-06-81). The average size of the palladium crystalline domains was determined by using the Debye–Scherrer formula [68], from the (111) X-ray line broadening, corrected for the instrumental broadening, by using LaB6 as an external peak profile standard. The average crystalline domain size of the PdNPs on α-ZrPK is estimated to be about 9nm, in good agreement with the data obtained from TEM analysis. A Pd content of 1mmol/g (10.6wt%) was determined by ICP-OES analysis. It should be noticed that this high palladium loading value is very useful in view of larger scale protocols, allowing the use of minimal quantities of catalytic material. 3.2 Catalytic activity We started our investigation testing the catalytic activity of PdNP/α-ZrPK in the Heck reaction between iodobenzene (1a) e methyl acrylate (2) in CH3CN/H2O azeotrope (Table 1 ). In the presence of triethylamine (TEA) as the base, at 70°C the conversion after 24h is only 66% (Table 1, entry 1). Increasing the reaction temperature up to 90°C the reaction was complete after 24h (Table 1, entry 2). The time required to reach complete conversion of 1a decreased to 3h when the reaction was performed at 120°C (Table 1, entry 3). Decreasing the amount of Pd from 0.1 to 0.01mol%, the conversion of 1a to 3a, after 3h at 120°C, strongly decreased to 32% (Table 1, entry 3). The ICP-OES analyses of crude products, obtained by standard work-up procedure (filtration, extraction with ethyl acetate, evaporation of solvent under reduced pressure), revealed the presence of palladium. It is known that Heck reaction may proceed through a “release and catch” mechanism [21,61,69–75] and that common dipolar aprotic media and some organic bases strongly bind the soluble palladium species, facilitating its dissolution from the support and consequently the leaching into the products [76–78]. On this regard, it should be considered that, although the palladium amount exceeded the allowed upper limit value [79], the percentage of Pd leaching was less than 4.5%, with respect to the initial amount in the PdNP/α-ZrPK catalyst. It should be noticed that, besides the Pd leaching is often limited at higher temperatures [74,80], in this case an increase in the reaction temperature from 90 to 120°C had a minimal influence on the palladium contamination of the products (Table 1, entry 3 vs 2). This may be due to the complexing ability of the homogenous TEA [76–78]. In order to simplify the work-up procedure, but also reduce the leaching, we investigated the use of a heterogeneous base, namely diethylaminomethyl-polystyrene (PS-TEA) which can be removed by simple filtration of the reaction mixture, therefore making possible the isolation of the final product after the distillation of the azeotropic reaction medium. As aforementioned, a homogeneous tertiary amine is generally used for its fundamental role in regenerating the active palladium species [81], with the consequent formation of the corresponding ammonium salt. Therefore, purification steps such as extraction or column chromatography are normally needed to remove the salt, leading to the production of a great amount of waste. Indeed, the resulting environmental factor (E-factor) values (kg of waste/kg of isolated desired product) in academic literature protocols are generally very high [82,83]. As shown in Table 1, when the reaction was performed in the presence of PS-TEA, the catalytic activity was unchanged while the Pd leaching greatly decreased (Table 1, entries 4 and 5). Indeed, at 120°C (Table 1, entry 5) the Pd content in the product is only 6ppm, very close to the allowed limit value [79]. It is reasonable to suppose that the polystyrene-bonded amino groups can act as capping agents for the PdNPs, as a result the Pd leaching is noticeably reduced [84–87]. At this point, in order to evaluate the robustness of the prepared catalyst and thus its recovery and reuse, recycle tests were performed in batch, for the reaction with homogeneous TEA. In fact, when PS-TEA is used in batch, it is not possible to separate the catalytic material from the heterogeneous base at the end of the reaction. For each cycle, the catalyst is recovered by centrifugation, washed with CH3CN azeotrope and reused in the next cycle (Table 2 ). The solid catalyst was used six times without loss of activity achieving a TON of ca. 6000 and a TOF of ca. 333h−1. Conversion after 1h of reaction time was also evaluated and a consistent conversion of 1a to 3a of ca. 36% was observed in all the cycles. The ICP-OES analyses of crude products confirmed that the palladium leaching was relatively high in the first cycle, but it decreased in the successive cycle suggesting a stabilization of the PdNP/α-ZrPK catalyst. In Fig. 3 the TEM images of PdNP/α-ZrPK after six cycles are shown. The PdNPs still have a spherical morphology with a good monodispersity, but the particles size range increased from 5–20nm of the starting material (Fig. 1) to 15–60nm after six cycles. The little increase of particles size doesn’t affect the catalytic activity but gives an increased stability to the immobilized palladium nanoparticles. To confirm the efficiency of PdNP/α-ZrPK in the Heck reaction, we extended the coupling to several aryl iodides (1a–h) with methyl acrylate (2) (Table 3 ) and styrene (5) (Table 4 ). The reactions of the aryl iodides (1a–h) with methyl acrylate (2) (Table 3) were carried at 120°C for 3h, in presence of 0.1mol% of PdNP/α-ZrPK, obtaining from high to quantitative conversions of 1 and excellent yields of isolated products 3a–h. For 4-nitro-iodobenzene (1b), 2’-iodoacetophenone (1f) and 2-iodothiophene (1h) we observed the formation of the corresponding homocoupling products: the biphenyls 4b, 4f and 4h and therefore the products 3b, 3f and 3h were purified by column chromatography (Table 3, entries 2, 6 and 8). When styrene (5) was used with iodobenzene (1a), longer reaction time was needed to achieve quantitative conversion (Table 4, entries 1–2). Therefore, a reaction time of 4h was adopted in the reactions between the aryl iodides 1a–h and styrene (5) (Table 4, entries 2–9). In all cases we observed the formation of the gem-products 7a–h and for 2’-iodoacetophenone (1f) and 2-iodothiophene (1h) we observed also the formation of the corresponding homocoupling products, namely the biphenyls 4f and 4h (Table 4, entries 7 and 9). According to our project, we have also defined a flow procedure to optimize the efficiency of the process and simplify the isolation of the pure products, while minimizing the waste production. In order to study the catalytic behavior of the prepared catalyst, PdNP/α-ZrPK, under flow conditions, the Heck reaction between iodobenzene (1a) and methyl acrylate (2) was selected as representative model process using CH3CN/H2O azeotrope as medium and the heterogeneous PS-TEA as base. We realized the flow protocol by charging a mixture of the catalyst PdNP/α-ZrPK and the supported base PS-TEA (1.5 equiv) in a stainless-steel HPLC column, while the reactants solution was charged in another glass column, acting as the reservoir (Scheme 1 ). All the equipment was connected, by using the appropriate valves, to a pump and installed into a thermostated box (not shown in Scheme 1 for clarity). After setting the temperature at 120°C, the reaction mixture was cyclically pumped through the columns at a 2.0mL/min flow rate for the time required to obtain quantitative conversion of 1a to 3a (8h, monitored by GLC). The column containing the PS-TEA and catalyst was then cyclically washed with acetonitrile/water azeotrope (0.5mL/mmol, 3 times at 2mL/min) to clean all the equipment and completely recover the product 3a. Finally, the product was isolated in high purity after distillation of the medium at ambient pressure, without any further purification step, in 89% yield. The ICP analyses revealed a Pd content of ca. 6ppm. The CH3CN aqueous azeotrope distilled off after reaction complexion, was recovered with a high purity (GLC analysis), totally comparable to the starting azeotropic mixture, thus being reusable without affecting the reaction yield. To evaluate the waste minimization we calculated the E-Factor value for both the batch and the flow protocol. The reaction performed in batch using TEA as the base featured an E-Factor value of 70.4, mainly affected by the need of extraction work-up. Using PS-TEA under flow conditions on a larger scale (50mmol) we were able to reduce this value to 4.6, since no purification steps were required and the reaction medium was recovered. Performing the reaction in cyclic flow conditions we were able to exploit the aforementioned “release and catch” mechanism [21,61,69–75], in which the supported palladium nanoparticles serve as reservoir for active Pd species that are dissolved from the solid catalyst and can move through the flow apparatus. The soluble Pd species are then effectively scavenged by the support after reaction completion, as proved by the low level of residual Pd in the products. Alternatively, direct flow conditions furnished unreacted product with increased palladium content. 4 Conclusion In this contribution we reported the preparation of an efficient and recyclable catalyst for the Heck cross-coupling reaction, based on palladium nanoparticles supported on layered potassium α-zirconium phosphate. The catalytic material features a high palladium loading (1mmol/g), allowing its use in minimal quantity, moreover it proved to be recoverable and recyclable. We successfully used a promising recoverable medium, i.e. the acetonitrile/water azeotrope, which can be an effective alternative to highly toxic dipolar aprotic solvent, such as DMF, commonly used in Heck cross-coupling reaction. A great reduction of the waste produced was given by the combined use of a recoverable medium and a heterogeneous base, which was removed from the reaction mixture by simple filtration, avoiding wasteful work up procedures. Finally, the flow technology has proved to be an alternative efficient stirring method, able to preserve the physical integrity and activity of the heterogeneous catalyst and contribute to waste minimization. Indeed with the flow approach we were able to noticeably simplify the experimental procedures and to achieve an E-Factor reduction from 70.4 to 4.6. coredata.dc:description: Palladium nanoparticles on layered potassium α-zirconium phosphate (PdNP/α-ZrPK) with high palladium loading (10.6wt%) have been prepared and used as catalyst in low amount (0.1mol% of Pd) in the Heck reaction of methyl acrylate and styrene with a series of aryl iodides in CH3CN/H2O azeotrope as a green medium. The procedure has been optimized under flow conditions obtaining an extremely low waste production (E-factor) and allowing to isolate the final product with very low residual palladium content without any purification step.
coredata.dc:title: Immobilized palladium nanoparticles on potassium zirconium phosphate as an efficient recoverable heterogeneous catalyst for a clean Heck reaction in flow
